interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2018/03/22
Average Rating: 3.9
Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['None'], 'Starring': ['Ruth Blackwell'], 'Studio': ['Independent Documentary']}
Review Text: Water faucets running and junk scattered on the floor. That HAD to be a ghost! I now believe in ghosts! This was a lower budget Blair Witch Project that was hoping a large percentage of the people were too young to remember The Blair Witch Project. The only reason it barely made it to three stars is that it's a cute couple. And they did get me to watch the whole thing. This was very terrible.
Review Title: This was very terrible.
Rating: 3.0
--------------------------------------------------

I got this movie to watch with my mom because she grew up on the East Coast around this time. It's a sweet movie with a little R ish material, not too much, but all in all a nice escape, and a movie that stands up to rewatching.
It's a sweet movie with a little R ish material
{'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Henry Singer'], 'Producers': ['Henry Singer'], 'Studio': ['XiveTV']}
They should retitle this one "The Most Narcissistic Photographer in the History of Photographs". This guy tried to make the entire story about him, a guy who pushed a button on a machine. Line after line of how he was Picasso, how his photograph compared to Pulitzer Prize winning photos, every last thing the guy said was about himself. I defy you to find a sentence without the word "I" or "me" in it.
The Most Narcissistic Photographer in the History of Photographs

Out after 40 seconds. I at first couldn't realize if the video was warped, or the guy had a speech impediment. No way could I make it through 90 minutes of that.

profile:
**User Summary:**

The user maintains a strong affinity for comedy films that blend elements of drama and nostalgia, emphasizing narratives rich in personal connections and cultural experiences. Their discerning taste reveals a clear preference for balanced storytelling and in-depth character exploration, with a notable aversion to self-absorbed protagonists. 

Recent interactions have highlighted a growing intolerance for subpar execution in filmmaking. The user's latest review reflects a critical stance on an independent film they found lacking in coherence, despite acknowledging the charm of the lead couple. This shift underscores their exacting standards for emotional engagement and narrative clarity, as they expect a strong connection to the content they consume.

Their engagement with multi-language audio and subtitles continues to enhance their viewing experience, emphasizing a commitment to accessible storytelling. The user's feedback style remains balanced, concentrating on emotional impact and entertainment value, yet they seem less forgiving of poorly executed narratives.

Overall, this profile illustrates a sophisticated viewer who prizes quality storytelling and character development, seeking films that offer warmth and a nuanced exploration of complex themes. Their recent experiences emphasize an increasing demand for coherence and quality, indicating a more critical approach to their cinematic choices while still remaining open to diverse narratives.
